div1.p: Hench explains to Secretary of State Acheson the work of Finlay and the Yellow Fever Commission, the Finlay-Reed controversy, the rediscovery and eventual memorialization of Camp Lazear, and the significance of Ambassador Beaulac's actions in facilitating American participation at the dedication.

head.hi:
Addendum
Significance of Cuba's Memorial at “Camp Lazear” (Havana): The Importance
of the Official American (Diplomatic) Participation in the Dedication

list.item:
1. The Cuban physician, Dr. Carlos Finlay, first developed, in 1881, the
brilliant theory that yellow fever, then a terrible scourge to Cuba and to
the United States, was caused by a certain mosquito. For 19 years (1881 -
1900) he worked to prove his theory but because his results were inconclusive
he was almost completely ignored by the Cubans as well as by the world.

2. In 1900 the Surgeon General, U.S. Army, sent a four-man Medical Board
(Reed, Carroll, Agramonte, Lazear) to study yellow fever in Cuba. After one
false start they were able to prove the Finlay theory so that yellow fever
has largely been controlled. The second, most important phase of their work
was done in two little specially constructed wooden buildings at an experi-
mental station named “Camp Lazear,” just outside Havana. This was truly the
site where yellow fever was “conquered.”

3. By coincidence “Camp Lazear” was part of the Finca (farm) San Jose, in
the main house of which (Quinta San Jose) Finlay had in 1883 performed five
of his experiments. Although Finlay did no experimental work at Camp Lazear
(1900 - 1901) he visited it many times (with Reed) as the senior member of
the Havana Yellow Fever Board which verified all diagnoses of yellow fever
in or near Havana. Thus the Finca San Jose and Camp Lazear above all places
united the aspirations, and symbolized the inter-relationship, between Finlay
and the Americans.

4. For a short time only (December 1900 - summer 1901) Reed and his associates
shared with Finlay the admiring respect of the Cuban people and medical pro-
fession. But when the American workers found it necessary (1901 - 1902) to
point out the differences between their work and that of Finlay, and the in-
conclusiveness of Finlay's work (as contrasted to the correctness of his
theory) there began in Cuba an undignified and often acrimonious debate regarding
priority and the relative merits of those concerned.

5. For 50 years certain Cuban elements (physicians, writers, publications)
have carried on this unhappy, unilateral campaign of “justification” (almost
deification) of Finlay and belittling of the American Medical Board: “The
American Army and the American medical associates robbed Finlay of his glory.”
The campaign has not been materially lessened despite a growing understanding
of the American viewpoint by certain important senior Cuban physicians.

6. In 1940 the “lost site” of Camp Lazear and the actual remains of one of
Reed's experimental buildings were rediscovered by an American physician with
the help of two “Cubans.” Certain Americans and Cubans agreed that if this
historic spot could be preserved as a Cuban-American memorial to Finlay and
Reed and the associates of both (i.e. to all the conquerors of yellow fever)
it might initiate a new spirit of Cuban-American friendship (professional,
popular and governmental) and stop at last the undignified anti-American
(anti-Reed) speeches and articles.

7. It took twelve years (1940 - 1952) before the Cuban Government was pre-
pared to act. But in 1952 the Cuban Government (of Prio) did restore Reed's
historic little building and surrounded it with a small memorial park with
bronze memorials. Despite some residual chauvinistic pressure, the Cuban
Government chose the official designation “Monumento Nacional Parque Campamento
Lazear,” set December 3, 1952, for the dedication and invited certain Americans:
relatives of Reed, Carroll, Lazear; the sole surviving soldier-volunteer, and
representatives of the Army Medical Corps and other American organizations.
Here at last was an occasion for “burying the hatchet” and extending mutual
felicitations all around.

8. The Americans concerned recognized the importance of an active and
sympathetic participation with the Cubans, to recognize their friendly,
gracious act toward the American Army Board and to “match it” with expres-
sions of United States friendship for Doctors Finlay and Delgado. Thirteen
American organizations (medical schools, associations, the Army) appointed
representatives to lay floral tributes to Dr. Finlay (as well as to Reed,
et al) at the dedication. Because in the past the Cuban malcontents have
regarded the Army Medical Corps and the American Medical Association as
the chief “detractors” of Finlay, the friendly representatives of those
two organizations were the most important ones to be at the ceremony.

9. But because of two unexpected circumstances (the Eastern Airlines strike
and the bad east-coast storm of December 1 - 2) the most important American
representatives (from the “diplomatic” standpoint) were unable to reach
Havana, chief among them Major General Streit, Commanding General of Walter
Reed Hospital, who was representing Surgeon General George Armstrong. Thus
on the morning of the dedication (the climax of twelve years of hoping and
planning on the part of certain Americans) it looked as if the important
American tribute to Cuban medical science would fall through since the other
Americans present were civilians of academic standing but of no official or
military importance as far as the Cubans were concerned.

10. When Ambassador Beaulac learned of this embarrassing situation, recognizing
the peculiar importance of having American official participation, he quickly
offered the services of his staff, and brought with him and Mrs. Beaulac to the
ceremony his aides. To the great satisfaction of the Cubans (and to the great
relief of the Americans concerned) Ambassador Beaulac accepted the invitation
of the Cuban governmental representative (Minister of Health) to unveil the
memorial to Walter Reed. Then four members of the Embassy staff, Mr. Earl
Crain, Major Lampner (Medical Corps), Colonel Mason and Lt. Colonel Elmore,
participated as most fitting and appropriate substitutes during other parts
of the ceremony, only a very few Cubans knowing that they were substitutes.

11. Their participation pleased the Cubans greatly and was widely noted in
the Cuban press which used quite a few photographs of these American participators
at the ceremony.

12. What could have been a lame and unimpressive affair from the standpoint
of American participation and expressions of our appreciation was thus carried
out in a manner which seemed to be gratifying to all concerned. A new spirit
of Cuban-American friendship (at least medical) was definitely apparent, and
was enhanced by the reception given by Ambassador and Mrs. Beaulac at the
Embassy Residence, for many Cuban personalities, and by the dinner given for
certain American guests by President and Senora Batista.
